notes.note: You can now close a Picture-in-Picture window without pausing the video. Press Shift + Click on the close button or use Shift + Esc to exit while keeping playback uninterrupted.

Logins in the [Firefox Password Manager][1] are now encrypted using a more modern encryption scheme, switching from 3DES-CBC to AES-256-CBC. This change only affects the local encryption of logins on the disk; logins synced through Firefox Sync are end-to-end encrypted independently and have already been using a strong encryption scheme (AES-256-GCM) previously.


  [1]: https://support.mozilla.org/kb/manage-your-logins-firefox-password-manager
On Firefox for Android, a new translations banner now informs you of the translation status of the current webpage.
On Windows, when opening a link from another application, Firefox will only use a window on the current virtual desktop or open a new window if needed.
On Firefox for Android, the "Allow screenshots in private browsing" setting has been removed.

Firefox now supports the [WebGPU][1] [GPUDevice.importExternalTexture][2] API on Windows.


  [1]: https://developer.mozilla.org/docs/Web/API/WebGPU_API
  [2]: https://developer.mozilla.org/docs/Web/API/GPUDevice/importExternalTexture

Firefox now supports [PerformanceEventTiming.interactionId][1], allowing developers to group related input events. This enables support for the [Interaction to Next Paint][2] (INP) responsiveness metric.


  [1]: https://developer.mozilla.org/docs/Web/API/PerformanceEventTiming/interactionId
  [2]: https://developer.mozilla.org/docs/Glossary/Interaction_to_next_paint
Firefox now supports the `command` and `commandfor` attributes.

Firefox now supports the [View Transitions][1] API Level 1. The View Transitions API provides a mechanism for easily creating animated transitions between different website views.


  [1]: https://developer.mozilla.org/docs/Web/API/View_Transition_API

The `resizeMode` [getUserMedia][1] constraint is now available, allowing developers to crop and downscale video captured from a camera to any resolution they choose.


  [1]: https://developer.mozilla.org/docs/Web/API/MediaDevices/getUserMedia

Dithering is now applied when [linear-gradient][1], [conic-gradient][2], and [radial-gradient][3] are rendered using hardware WebRender.


  [1]: https://developer.mozilla.org/docs/Web/CSS/gradient/linear-gradient
  [2]: https://developer.mozilla.org/docs/Web/CSS/gradient/conic-gradient
  [3]: https://developer.mozilla.org/docs/Web/CSS/gradient/radial-gradient

Firefox now supports the [upsert proposal][1]. This adds `getOrInsert` and `getOrInsertComputed` methods to `Map` and `WeakMap`. These methods either return the value associated with a key, or insert a default value, and then return that value, simplifying handling of cases where it's not known if a key is already present in the `Map` or `WeakMap`.


  [1]: https://github.com/tc39/proposal-upsert

Firefox now supports the `lock()` and `unlock()` methods of [ScreenOrientation][1] interface on Windows tablets and Android devices.


  [1]: https://developer.mozilla.org/docs/Web/API/ScreenOrientation

[WebCodecs][1] on Windows now has a batch-encoding path for VideoEncoder, improving performance with higher throughput and lower submission latency due to a larger default batch size.


  [1]: https://developer.mozilla.org/docs/Web/API/WebCodecs_API

system_requirements:
## Windows

### Operating Systems (32-bit and 64-bit)
 - Windows 10 or later

### Recommended Hardware
-  1 gigahertz (GHz) or faster compatible processor or System on a Chip (SoC)
-  1GB of RAM / 2GB of RAM for the 64-bit version
-  500MB of hard drive space

---

## Mac

### Operating Systems
- macOS 10.15 or later

### Recommended Hardware
- Macintosh computer with an Intel x86 or Apple silicon processor
- 512 MB of RAM
- 200 MB hard drive space

---

## GNU/Linux

### Software Requirements

*Please note that GNU/Linux distributors may provide packages for your distribution which have different requirements.*

- Firefox will not run at all without the following libraries or packages:
    - glibc 2.17 or higher (2.28 or higher on arm64)
    - GTK+ 3.14 or higher
    - libglib 2.42 or higher
    - libstdc++ 4.8.1 or higher (6.0 or higher on arm64)
    - X.Org 1.0 or higher (1.7 or higher is recommended)
- For optimal functionality, we recommend the following libraries or packages:
    - DBus 1.0 or higher
    - NetworkManager 0.7 or higher
    - PulseAudio
text:
Firefox Beta gets updated 3 times a week and as a consequence, the release notes for the Beta channel are updated continuously to reflect features that have reached sufficient maturity to benefit from community feedback and bug reports.

**Warning: Features listed here may or may *not* make a final release of Firefox.**

In addition to these release notes, you can follow ongoing development via the [Firefox Trains][1] website or our [@FirefoxBeta][2] Bluesky account.


  [1]: https://whattrainisitnow.com/beta/
  [2]: https://bsky.app/profile/firefoxbeta.bsky.social
title: Firefox 144.0beta Beta
